history.content: Most people don't get to intern the summer after freshman year (unless you have significant programming experience from high school or can get into some diversity-focused program like Google Engineering Practicum or Facebook University) and typically take summer classes. Though small startups are often willing to hire you (with less/no pay) if you can prove yourself.

children.subject: Berkeley SkyDeck might be a good place to start.
I had poor experiences working as a “SWE” intern at Berkeley SkyDeck. Consisted of coffee runs and business card sorting. Check AngelList for startup internships.
Any way I can find these startups or do I just google startups?
Which companies actually ask for official transcripts?

Apparently very few, but it does happen-- see @9647. Google does, for instance, and at the beginning of the process at that. Also, some startups and small companies may e.g. a smaller tech consulting/investing firm I interviewed with for this coming summer did.

don't have a list but I remember google does

instead of saying you're a sophomore, if you want to seem more advanced than you are, just say you're graduating a year earlier than you actually are

^ This is a bit safer; but still a little risky if you do have to send your transcript, as CalCentral states your expected grad date; and you must petition to change it I believe. I think for most cases it wouldn't be a big deal.

Probably don't say you are a sophomore as they may ask for a transcript at some point during the interview process. It’s also much easier after freshman year for several reasons; and as far as doing well on the interviews, taking 61B helps a lot, which freshman will not typically have completed until after their first Spring semester, by which time recruiting will have passed. I didn't get one my freshman year, so I just did summer classes, which allowed me to take 170 my sophomore fall and do well on my internship interview and secure a summer position. Good luck!

My freshman year I got an offer from Facebook University by applying online and from PayPal by talking to their booth at the career fair in late January. Also just apply online to as many online applications as you can find! You'll find that response rates are pretty low, so it kinda just comes down to the numbers.

history.content:
How did you guys get an internship freshman year? Did you just say that you were a sophomore and hope you did well on the interview? Anyone have tips?
Thanks
history.subject: SWE internships for freshman
